issue.title: Enable liboqs build in UEFI/EDKII.
issue.body:
UEFI/EDKII used openssl as crypto lib with OPENSSL_SYS_UEFI.

This patch adds __UEFI__ macro in liboqs to indicate special build in UEFI/EDKII.
With this patch, we can start building liboqs in UEFI/EDKII.

For algorithm specific patches, we will submit one by one later.

Signed-off-by: Jiewen Yao <jiewen.yao@intel.com>

comment.body:
Sure.
UEFI specification (https://uefi.org/) describes the interface between system firmware (also known as BIOS) and operating system. EDKII (https://www.tianocore.org/, https://github.com/tianocore/edk2) is an implementation for the UEFI specification and is widely deployed in Personal Computer and Server.

EDKII is using openssl (https://github.com/tianocore/edk2/tree/master/CryptoPkg/Library/OpensslLib) as crypto engine for security features, such as UEFI secure boot image verification (https://github.com/tianocore/edk2/tree/master/SecurityPkg/Library/DxeImageVerificationLib), and HTTPS boot (https://github.com/tianocore/edk2/tree/master/NetworkPkg/HttpDxe).

Now, we are evaluating post-quantum cryptography (PQC) support in UEFI/EDKII, and have UEFI proof-of-concept (https://github.com/jyao1/CryptoEx/tree/master/QuantumSafePkg). We are using liboqs (https://github.com/jyao1/liboqs/tree/UefiSupport).

UEFI/EDKII can be built with Microsoft visual studio, GCC, or llvm. But UEFI/EDKII cannot link with any std lib. In order to use liboqs, we need change the code to make it buildable in the UEFI/EDKII environment.

We take same approach as what we have done for openssl (https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/include/openssl/e_os2.h#L48).

issue.title: Enable liboqs build in UEFI/EDKII.
issue.body:
UEFI/EDKII used openssl as crypto lib with OPENSSL_SYS_UEFI.

This patch adds __UEFI__ macro in liboqs to indicate special build in UEFI/EDKII.
With this patch, we can start building liboqs in UEFI/EDKII.

For algorithm specific patches, we will submit one by one later.

Signed-off-by: Jiewen Yao <jiewen.yao@intel.com>

comment.body: Thanks for the explanations, @jyao1 -- Could you explain why you are using the pretty generic `__UEFI__` here to toggle this behaviour as opposed to the more "controlled" `OPENSSL_SYS_UEFI` in OpenSSL? Couldn't it be so that some package inadvertently sets this #define? Or asked another way around, what about using a define such as `OQS_SYS_UEFI` instead?

issue.title: Enable liboqs build in UEFI/EDKII.
issue.body:

comment.body:
No special reason.
I am happy to use OQS_SYS_UEFI. I will change it.

issue.title: Enable liboqs build in UEFI/EDKII.
issue.body:
UEFI/EDKII used openssl as crypto lib with OPENSSL_SYS_UEFI.

This patch adds OQS_SYS_UEFI macro in liboqs to indicate special build in UEFI/EDKII.
With this patch, we can start building liboqs in UEFI/EDKII.

For algorithm specific patches, we will submit one by one later.

Signed-off-by: Jiewen Yao <jiewen.yao@intel.com>

issue.title: Decide on further profiling runs
issue.body:
Now that additional AWS credits are available, decide which additional things to profile.

Options: Different CPU types (AMD, ARM (which), ...?) New OSs (OSX, Windows, RedHat, ... -- some possibly on ARM64) further network simulations, ...???

Input solicited: Additional options? Priorities?

Edit: Instance types: https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/

comment.body:
> I don't have a good sense of the pros for Alpine

I don't either (any more: It had been size, but after creating a size-optimized Debian container, we now know it's 509MB -- vs 493 for Alpine). Doing a test run now; let's see what that delivers.

issue.title: Take stock of all algorithms
issue.body:
This issue to capture what we discussed today (also for the benefit of @christianpaquin): 

- Create a current view as to where we stand for each algorithm (round3 readiness, code level, etc.)
- Decide whether/how to parcel out work to arrive at 0.5 release readiness (incl. whether/how to address common code issues as per #849).
- Probably also list release-criteria for 0.5 (not discussed today but in a previous meeting).

@dstebila @xvzcf are working on this.

comment.body: Last remaining issue before releasing 0.6, right? Would it be an idea to complete a release of liboqs and all subprojects before the end of May/PQC workshop? For 0.5 it took us a month to move from RC on liboqs until final release of all subprojects... Thus, what about focusing on/closing this now and having a liboqs-0.6 RC by the end of April?

issue.title: Enable liboqs build in UEFI/EDKII.
issue.body:
UEFI/EDKII used openssl as crypto lib with OPENSSL_SYS_UEFI.

This patch adds OQS_SYS_UEFI macro in liboqs to indicate special build in UEFI/EDKII.
With this patch, we can start building liboqs in UEFI/EDKII.

For algorithm specific patches, we will submit one by one later.

Signed-off-by: Jiewen Yao <jiewen.yao@intel.com>

comment.body: Thanks for the explanation. I've merged this. If you can think about whether it's possible to add something to our continuous integration checks to ensure that this functionality is tested, that would be best, otherwise we'll not know if any subsequent changes regress this.

issue.body:
This issue to capture what we discussed today (also for the benefit of @christianpaquin): 

- Create a current view as to where we stand for each algorithm (round3 readiness, code level, etc.)
- Decide whether/how to parcel out work to arrive at 0.5 release readiness (incl. whether/how to address common code issues as per #849).
- Probably also list release-criteria for 0.5 (not discussed today but in a previous meeting).

comment.body: Greed. @xvzcf have you made any progress on generating documentation from the sample YML file?

issue.title: Question: How to vary the signature size?
issue.body: Hi, I am a bit confused when it comes to varying the signature size & the key sizes. According to the Liboqs documentation in C, the OQS_SIG_sign should contain the following parameters such as the signature size. What would be the corresponding class/function containing such parameters?

comment.body: @invalidexplorer Not sure I understand. The signature size is fixed for a given sig algorithm, and the wrapper takes care of it automatically. Can you post a code snippet so I understand the issue?
